section: Client acknowledges and agrees that any due dates set forth in the Scope of Work are not subject to any delay.
explanation: This statement is overly rigid and potentially unenforceable. Unforeseen circumstances (e.g., illness, natural disasters, third-party failures) could legitimately prevent the Company from meeting the deadlines. A clause stating that due dates are 'not subject to any delay' is inherently unreasonable and could be considered a legal contradiction because it doesn't account for 'force majeure' events which are legally recognized reasons for excusable delays.

section: Company will not make any attempt to proof read or correct any contextual, grammatical or typographical errors in the written content submitted by Client. It is Client's sole responsibility to check the accuracy of the written content and correct any errors prior to submission for final publication. Company will assume that all the written content submitted by Client has been proofread and is ready for publication. Client may elect to pay Company the Hourly Rate set forth below to type and proofread any written content not submitted in the electronic formats specified above.
explanation: This section contains internal inconsistencies. It initially states the Company will make no attempt to proofread client's content. However, it subsequently allows the Client to pay the Company's hourly rate for typing and proofreading. This creates an ambiguity: if the client pays for proofreading, does the company then have a responsibility to proofread? The initial statement denies any such responsibility, while the option to pay implies acceptance of that responsibility when paid.

section: Client agrees that any unsolicited positive feedback Client provides to Company may be used in any Company marketing and/or advertising materials (i.e., customer testimonials).
explanation: This section is ambiguous and potentially violates privacy laws or regulations regarding the use of testimonials. It lacks clarity on key aspects: Does the company need explicit consent before using a client's positive feedback? Are there any restrictions on how the feedback will be used (e.g., can it be altered or selectively quoted)? Without addressing these points, the clause could be interpreted as an overreach by the company to use potentially sensitive information without clear consent, which could pose legal issues.
